page.title: 02General description.
page.content: Leighton-Linslade was two towns separated by the river Ouzel. Leighton derives from "Leactun" (a kitchen garden) and Linslade derives from "Hlincgelad" (a sandy bank by the side of a stream). St. Mary's church in Old Linslade is Norman in nucleus. It is rarely open to the public. Linslade Manor and the converted water-mill are both mentioned in the Domesday Book of 1068. Soulbury overlooks the Ouzel valley and comprises of several half timbered and thatched houses around a green and an attractive 14th century church. Buildings of note are Lovetts Charity School House built in 1724, Chelmscote Manor and Liscombe Manor (large, rambling and built in the 16th century). There are remains of 14th century chapels in both manor grounds.
